TextEquiv.Unicode: Perſonal-Veränderungen in der Armee.
Perſonal-Veränderungen in der Armee.
Offiziere, Portepee⸗Fähnriche ꝛc.
Offiziere, Portepee⸗Fähnriche ꝛc.
A. Ernennungen, Beförderungen und Verſetzungen.
Den 18. Oktober. v. Schrötter, Major von Gen. Stabe
der 1. Div., unter Stellung à la suite des Gen. Stabes der Armee,
zum Direktor der Kriegsſchule in Metz ernannt. Treplin, Sec. Lt.
vom 2. Magdeb. Inf. Regt. Nr. 27, in ſeinem Kommdo. als Bureau⸗
Chef und Bibliothekar von der Kriegsſchule in Engers zur Kriegs⸗
ſchule in Metz verſetzt. v. Duisburg I., Pr. Lt. vom 5. Weſtfäl.
Inf. Regt. Nr. 53, als Bureau⸗Chef und Bibliothekar zur Kriegs⸗
ſchule in Engers kommandirt. Meyer, Pr. Lt. vom Hannov. Füſ.
Regt. Nr. 73, als Bureau⸗Chef und Bibliothekar zur Kriegsſchule in
Hannover kommand. v. Dresler u. Scharfenſtein, Pr. Lt. vom
1. Mageburg. Inf. Regt. Nr 26, von ſeinem Kommdo. als Bureau⸗
Chef und Bibliothekar bei der Kriegsſchule zu Erſurt entbunden.
v. Brandenſtein, Pr. Lt. vom 6. Thüring. Inf. Regt. Nr. 95,
als Bureau⸗Chef u. Bibliothek. zur Kriegsſchule in Erfurt kommand.
v. Tſchiſchwitz, Hauptm. à la suite des 3. Brandenburg. Inf.
Regts. Nr. 20 und kommdrt. als Militär⸗Lehrer beim Kadettenhauſe
zu Culm, unter Belaſſung à la suite des gedachten Regts., als Comp.
Chef zum Kadettenhauſe in Potsdam kommdrt. v. Trotha, Pr. Lt.
vom Gren. Regt. König Friedrich Wilhelm IV. (1. Pomm.) Nr. 2
und kommandirt als Erzieher bei dem Kadettenhauſe in Potsdam,
als Aſſiſt. der Comp. Chefs bei demſ. Kadettenhauſe kommdrt. Wol⸗
lenhaupt, Sec. Lt. vom 1. Weſtpreuß. Gren. Regt. Nr. 6, in ſei⸗
nem Kommdo. als Erzieher vom Kadettenhauſe zu Wahlſtatt zum
Kadettenhauſe in Potsdam verſetzt. v. Rauſchenplat, Sec. Lt. vom
Magdeburg. Jäg. Bat. Nr. 4, als Erzieher zum Kadettenhauſe in
Plön vom 1. November cr. ab, vorläufig bis zum 1. Mai 1872
kommdrt. Simon, Sec. Lt. vom Kadettencorps, zum Prem. Lieut.
befördert.
Den 19. Oktober. v. Reckow, Oberſt à la suite des Weſt⸗
preuß. Ulanen⸗Regts. Nr. 1 und beauftragt mit der Führung der
29. Kav. Brig., v. Drigalski, Oberſt à la suite des 1., Brandenb.
Drag. Regts. Nr. 2 und beauftragt mit der Führung der 5. Kav.
Brig, v. Buſſe, Oberſt à la suite des 3. Schleſ. Drag. Regts.
Nr. 15 und beauftragt mit der Führung der 15. Kav. Brig., zu Com⸗
mandeuren dieſer Kav. Brigaden ernannt. v. Böhn, Ob. Lt. aggr.
dem 2. Hanſeat. Inf. Regt. Nr. 76 und kommdrt. zur Führung des
Regts, unter Stellung à la suite dieſes Regts., mit der Führung
deſſelben, v. Nitſche, Ob. Lt. aggr. dem 4. Bad. Inf. Regt. Prinz
Wilhelm Nr. 112 und kommdrt. zur Führung des Regts, unter Stel⸗
lung à la suite dieſes Regts. mit der Führung deſſelben, v. Grol⸗
man, Ob. Lt. vom 3. Garde⸗Grenadier⸗Regiment Königin Eliſabeth
und kommandirt zur Führung des 4. Garde⸗Regiments mit der Füh⸗
rung dieſes Regiments, unter Stellung à la suite deſſelben,
v. Oppell, Ob. Lt. vom 1. Garde⸗Regt. z. F. und kommandirt zur
Führung des 2. Garde⸗Regts, mit der Führung dieſes Regiments,
unter Stellung à la suite deſſelben, v. Sannow, Ob. Lt. aggr.
dem 3. Weſtf. Inf. Regt. Nr. 16, mit der Führung dieſes Regts.,
unter Stellung à la suite deſſelben, beauftragt. v. Altrock,
Hauptm. und Comp. Chef im 3. Garde Gren. Regt. Königin Eliſa⸗
beth, v. Roeder, Hauptm. u. Comp. Chef vom 1. Garde Regt.
z. F., zu Majors befördert. Lindemann, Hauptm. u. Comp. Chef
vom 4. Magdeb. Inf. Regt. Nr. 67, unter Stellung à la suite dieſes
Regts., zum Platzmajor in Diedenhofen ernannt. v. Zedtwitz,
Hauptm. u. Comp. Chef vom 4. Thür. Inf. Regt. Nr. 72, dem Regt.
aggr. und zur Wahrnehmung der Geſchäfte als Bezirks⸗Commdr. des
1. Bats. (Halberſtadt) 3. Magdeb. Landw. Regts. Nr. 66 komman⸗
dirt. Koſack, Hauptm. zur Disp. und Bezirks⸗Commandeur des
1. Bats. (Neuſtadt) 2. Poſ. Landw. Regt. Nr. 19, der Charakter als
Major verliehen.
Den 21. Oktober. v. Luck, Prem. Lt. à la suite des 2ten
Rhein. Huſ. Regts. Nr. 9, auf ein Jahr zur Geſandtſchaft in Bern
kommandirt.

A. Ernennungen, Beförderungen und Verſetzungen. Den 18. Oktober. v. Schrötter, Major von Gen. Stabe der 1. Div., unter Stellung à la suite des Gen. Stabes der Armee, zum Direktor der Kriegsſchule in Metz ernannt. Treplin, Sec. Lt. vom 2. Magdeb. Inf. Regt. Nr. 53, als Bureau⸗Chef und Bibliothekar zur Kriegs⸗ ſchule in Engers kommandirt. Meyer, Pr. Lt. vom Hannov. Füſ. Regt. Nr. 73, als Bureau⸗Chef und Bibliothekar zur Kriegsſchule in Hannover kommand. v. Dresler u. Scharfenſtein, Pr. Lt. vom 1. Mageburg. Inf. Regt. Regt. König Friedrich Wilhelm IV. (1. Pomm.) Nr. 2 und kommandirt als Erzieher bei dem Kadettenhauſe in Potsdam, als Aſſiſt. der Comp. Chefs bei demſ. Kadettenhauſe kommdrt. Wol⸗ lenhaupt, Sec. Nr. 4, als Erzieher zum Kadettenhauſe in Plön vom 1. November cr. ab, vorläufig bis zum 1. Mai 1872 kommdrt. Simon, Sec. Lt. vom Kadettencorps, zum Prem. Lieut. befördert. Den 19. Oktober. v. Nr. 2 und beauftragt mit der Führung der 5. Kav. Brig, v. Buſſe, Oberſt à la suite des 3. Schleſ. Drag. Regts. Nr. 15 und beauftragt mit der Führung der 15. Kav. Brig., zu Com⸗ mandeuren dieſer Kav. Lt. aggr. dem 4. Bad. Inf. Regt. Prinz Wilhelm Nr. 112 und kommdrt. zur Führung des Regts, unter Stel⸗ lung à la suite dieſes Regts. mit der Führung deſſelben, v. Grol⸗ man, Ob. Lt. vom 3. Huſ. Regts. Nr. 9, auf ein Jahr zur Geſandtſchaft in Bern kommandirt.
B. Abſchiedsbewilligungen ꝛc.
B. Abſchiedsbewilligungen ꝛc.
Den 18. Oktober. v. Bothmer, Gen. Maj. und Komman⸗
dant von Danzig, in Genehmigung ſeines Abſchieds⸗Geſuches, als
Gen. Lt. mit Penſ. zur Dispoſ. geſtellt. v. Wedell, Gen. Maj.
von der Armee, in Genehmigung ſeines Abſchieds⸗Geſuches, mit Pen⸗
ſion zur Disp. geſtellt.
Den 19. Oktober. v. Etzel, Gen. der Inf. und Gouverneur
von Stettin, in Genehmigung ſeines Abſchieds⸗Geſuches, mit Penſ.
zur Disp. geſtellt. Keller, Gen. Maj. und Commdr. der 57. Inf.
Brig., in Genehmigung ſeines Abſchieds⸗Geſuches, als Gen. Lt. mit
Penſ. z. Disp. geſtellt. v. Bodungen, Port. Fähnr. vom 3. Thür.
Inf. Regt. Nr. 71, ausgeſchieden, Meerwein, Sec. Lt. a. D., früher
im 4. Brandenb. Inf. Regt. Nr. 24 (Großherzog von Mecklenburg⸗
Schwerin), zuletzt bei der Inf. des 1. Bats. (Brandenburg a. H.)
4. Brandenb. Landw. Regts. Nr. 24, die bedingte Anſtellungs⸗Berech⸗
tigung im Civildienſt ertheilt.
Den 21. Oktober. v. Schenckendorff, Gen. Maj. z. Disp.,
zuletzt Commdr. der 10. Kav. Brig, der Charakter als Gen. Lt. ver⸗
liehen.

Den 18. Oktober. v. Bothmer, Gen. Maj. und Komman⸗ dant von Danzig, in Genehmigung ſeines Abſchieds⸗Geſuches, als Gen. Lt. mit Penſ. zur Dispoſ. geſtellt. v. Wedell, Gen. Maj. von der Armee, in Genehmigung ſeines Abſchieds⸗Geſuches, mit Pen⸗ ſion zur Disp. geſtellt. Den 19. Oktober. v. Brig., in Genehmigung ſeines Abſchieds⸗Geſuches, als Gen. Lt. mit Penſ. z. Disp. geſtellt. v. Bodungen, Port. Fähnr. vom 3. Thür. Inf. Regt. Nr. 71, ausgeſchieden, Meerwein, Sec. Lt. a. D., früher im 4. Brandenb. Inf. Regt. Nr. 24 (Großherzog von Mecklenburg⸗ Schwerin), zuletzt bei der Inf. des 1. Bats. (Brandenburg a. H.) 4. Brandenb. Landw. Regts. Nr. 24, die bedingte Anſtellungs⸗Berech⸗ tigung im Civildienſt ertheilt. Den 21. Oktober. v. Schenckendorff, Gen. Maj. z. Disp., zuletzt Commdr. der 10. Kav. Brig, der Charakter als Gen. Lt. ver⸗ liehen.
Nachweiſung
Nachweiſung
der vom 1. April bis ultimo Juni 1871 zur öffentichen Kenntniß ge⸗
kommenen Todesfälle von penſionirten und ausgeſchiedenen Offizieren
und Beamten der Königlich preußiſchen Armee.
Geſtorben ſind am 12. Dezember 1870: Müller, Major a. D.,
zuletzt Hauptm. in der 3. Art. Brig. Am 21. Dezember: Wilk,
Maj. a. D., zuletzt Hauptm. im jetzigen Brandenb. Füſ. Regt. Nr. 35.
Am 20. Januar 1871: v. Arnim, Ov. Lt. a. D, zuletzt Rittm. im

der vom 1. April bis ultimo Juni 1871 zur öffentichen Kenntniß ge⸗ kommenen Todesfälle von penſionirten und ausgeſchiedenen Offizieren und Beamten der Königlich preußiſchen Armee. Geſtorben ſind am 12. Dezember 1870: Müller, Major a. D., zuletzt Hauptm. in der 3. Art. Brig. Am 21. Dezember: Wilk, Maj. a. D., zuletzt Hauptm. im jetzigen Brandenb. Füſ. Regt. Nr. 35. Am 20. Januar 1871: v. Arnim, Ov. Lt. a. D, zuletzt Rittm. im
2. Garde⸗Ulanen⸗Regt. Am 24. Januar: Hoppe, Major a. D.,
zuletzt Hauptm. und Platz⸗Ingenieur in Coſel. Am 28. Januar:
Bormann, Major a. D., zuletzt Rittm. im jetzigen Weſtfäl. Kür.
Regt. Nr. 4. Im Januar: Staabs, Ob. Lt. z. D., zuletzt Major
im 6. Rhein. Inf. Regt. Nr. 68. Am 1. Februar: Kauder, Aſſiſtenz⸗
arzt a. D., zuletzt im Schleſ. Ulanen⸗Regt. Nr. 2. Am 12. Februar:
Berger, Oberſt a. D., zuletzt Commdr. des jetzigen 2. Rhein. Inf.
Regt. Nr. 28. Am 14. Februar: v. Reiche, Major a. D, zuletzt
in ehem. Hannov. Dienſten. Am 15. Februar: Mente, Oberſt
a. D., zuletzt Oberſt⸗Lieutenant in der 3. Artillerie⸗Brigade.
Am 1. März: Kosmann, Hauptm. a. D., zuletzt in der 5. Art.
Brig. und Verkrüzen, Hauptm. a. D., zuletzt im vorm. 3 Bat.
(Warendorf), jetzt 1. Weſtfäl. Landw. Regts. Nr. 13. Am. 4. März:
Dr. Lemke, Ob. Stabs⸗ und Regts. Arzt a. D., zuletzt im 3. Rhein.
Inf. Regt. Nr. 29. Am 7. März: Dr. Quehl, Ob. Stabs⸗Arzt
a. D., zuletzt im 3. Garde⸗Regt. z. F. Am 9. März: Zwick, Aſſiſt.
Arzt a. D, zuletzt bei der Art. Werkſtatt in Neiſſe. Am 10. März:
Schulze, Pr. Lt. a. D., zuletzt Sec. Lt. im jetzigen Thür. Ulanen⸗
Regt. Nr. 6 Am 12. März: Schumann, Major a. D., zuletzt
Hauptm. im jetzigen 2. Thür. Inf. Regt. Nr. 32. Am 13. März:
v. Schwerin, Maj. a. D., zuletzt Hauptmann im jetzigen 4. Pomm.
Inf. Regt. Nr. 21. Am 15. März: Meyer, Ob. Lt. a. D., zuletzt
in Oldenburgiſchen Dienſten, und Lauter, Juſtiz⸗Rath, Garn. Aud.
a. D, zuletzt in Erfurt. Am 24. März: Breymann, Hauptm.
a. D, zuletzt in ehem. Hannoverſchen Dienſten. Am 25. März:
Lehmann, Hauptm. a. D., zuletzt im jetzigen Rhein. Inf. Regt.
Nr. 30. Am 29. März: Jeniſch, Zeug⸗Hauptm. a. D., zuletzt
beim Art.⸗Dep. in Coblenz. Am 1. April: v. Wedell, Maj. a. D.,
zuletzt Hauptm. im jetzigen 3. Pommerſchen Inf. Regt. Nr. 14, und
Grawert, Zeug⸗Hauptm. a. D, zuletzt Zeug⸗Lt. b. Art.⸗Dep. in Weſel.
Am 3. April: v. Friedensburg, Oberſt z. D., zuletzt Bez. Commdr.
des 2. Bats. (Brieg) 4. Niederſchl. Landw. Regts. Nr. 51, und Jung⸗
hans, Major a. D, zuletzt im Brandenb. Train⸗Bat. Nr. 3. Am
5. April: Eſchment, Ob. Lt. a. D., zuletzt à la suite der 2. Art.
Brig. und Cmmdr. des Trains des II. Armee⸗Corps, und Kienitz,
Major a. D., zuletzt Führer des 2. Aufg. d. 2. Bats. (Treuenbrietzen)
jetzt 3. Brandb. Landw. Rgts. Nr. 20. Am 6. April: Gueinzius,
Gen. Lt. a. D., zuletzt Gen. Maj. und Direktor des Milit. Oekon.
Depart. Am 7. April: v. Gfug, Ob. Lt. a. D., zuletzt im jetzigen
Weſtfäl. Füſ. Regt. Nr. 37. Am 8. April: Schienmann, Major
a. D, zuletzt Rittmſtr. im jetzigen Litth. Drag. Regt. Nr. 1 (Prinz
Albrecht von Preußen), und Müller, Sec. Lt. a. D., zuletzt im
6. Brandenburg. Inf. Regt. Nr. 52. Am 10. April: André, Ob.
Lt. a. D., zuletzt Führer des 2. Aufg. des 2. Bats. (Soldin) jetzigen
1. Brandb. Ldw. Rgts. Nr. 8. Am 11. April: v. Schwartzenau,
Ob. Lt. a. D., zuletzt Maj. im vorm. 3. Bat. 3. Garde⸗Land. Regts.
Am 14. April: v. Dalwigk, Major a. D., zuletzt Hauptm. im
jetzigen 2. Weſtfäl. Infanterie⸗Regiment Nr. 15 (Prinz Friedrich der
Niederlande), und v. Natzmer, Prem. Lieut. a. D., zuletzt im
jetzigen Kolberg. Grenadier⸗Regiment (2. Pommerſchen) Nr. 9.
Am 15. April: v. Spörken, Gen. Lt. a. D., zuletzt bei der vor⸗
maligen Hannoverſchen Kavallerie, und Curio, Ob. Lt. a. D., zuletzt
Maj. und Commdr. des 1. Bats. (Aachen), jetzigen 1. Rhein. Landw.
Regts. Nr. 25. Am 20. April: v. Gerhardt, Ob. Lt. a. D., zu⸗
letzt Major im jetzigen Königs⸗Gren. Regt. (2. Weſtpreuß.) Nr. 7, und
Toll, Geh. Juſtiz⸗Rath und Ober⸗Auditeur a. D., zuletzt beim Ge⸗
neral⸗Auditoriat. Am 22. April: v. Quednow, Ob. Lt. z. D., zu⸗
letzt Major im jetzigen 3. Oſtpr. Gren. Regt. Nr. 4. Am 24. April:
Kayſer, Ob. Lt. a. D., zuletzt in der 8. Art. Brig. Am 25. April:
du Fresne v. Francheville, Pr. Lt. a. D., zuletzt Sec. Lt. im
2. Oſtpr. Gren. Regt. Nr. 3. Am 26. April: Kolewe, Hauptmann
a. D., zuletzt im vorm. 1. Bat. (Breslau) 10. Landw. Regts., dem⸗
nächſt Vorſtand der Handwerksſtätte des Niederſchleſ. Feld⸗Art. Regts.
Nr. 5. Am 27. April: v. Seebach, Major a. D., zuletzt Führer
des 2. Aufg. des 1. Bats. (Minden) 2. Weſtfäl. Landw. Regts. Nr. 15.
Am 28. April: Dr. Hoffa, Ob. St. Arzt a. D., zuletzt in der ehem.
Kurheſſ. Artill. Am 1. Mai: v. Stockhauſen, Maj. a. D, zuletzt
Hauptm. im 1. Weſtfäl. Inf. Regt. Nr. 13. Am 2. Mai: v. Wloſto,
Ob. Lt. a. D., zuletzt Major im jetzigen 2. Schleſ. Gren. Regt. Nr. 11.
Am 3. Mai: v. Derſchau, Hauptm. z. D., zuletzt im jetzigen Oſtpr.
Jäger⸗Bat. Nr. 1. Am 4. Mai: Lenz, Oberſt z. D., zuletzt Ob. Lt.
und Commdr. der vorm. 2. Pion. Abth. Am 6. Mai: Beyer, Pr.
Lt. a. D., zuletzt i. vorm. Reſ. Ldw. Bat. (Wohlau) 38. Inf. Rgts.
Am 7. Mai: v. Waldow, Major a. D, zuletzt Rittm. im jetzigen
1. Schleſ. Drag. Regt. Nr. 4. Am 10. Mai: Farthmann, Major
a. D., zuletzt Hauptm. im jetzigen 2. Oberſchleſ. Inf. Regt. Nr. 23. Am
16. Mai: Kellner, Lt. a. D., zuletzt in ehem. Hannov. Dienſten.
Am 18. Mai: Gr. v. d. Schulenburg⸗Emden, Oberſt a. D.,
zuletzt Maj. und Führer d. 2. Aufg. d. vorm. 1. Bats. (Halberſladt)
27. Landw. Regts. Am 24. April: Tronchin de Lortol, Oberſt
a. D, zuletzt als Maj. d. Regt. der Gardes du Corps aggr., dem⸗
nächſt Schloß⸗Hauptm. zu Benrath. Am 29. Mai: v. Ciriacy
Pr. Lt. a. D., zuletzt in der Gensd'amerie, demnächſt Poſtmeiſter in
Koſel. Am 30. Mai: v. Helmrich, Ob. Lt. a. D., zuletzt Maj.
im jetzigen 3. Oſtpr. Gren.⸗Regt. 4. Im Mai: Ebel, Ob. Lt. a. D.,
zuletzt in vorm. Nauſſauiſchen Dienſten. Am 3. Juni: v. Oertzen,
Rittm. a. D., zuletzt Pr. Lt. im 1. Bat. (Görlitz) jetzigen 1. Weſtpr.
Landw. Regts. Nr. 6, und Dr. Maréchaux, Aſſiſt. Arzt a. D.,
zuletzt in der 4. Art. Brig. Am 8. Juni: v. Prittwitz, General
d. Inf. a. D., zuletzt Gen. Lt. u. kommdr. Gen. d. Garde⸗Korps.

Maj. z. D., Oberſt u. Commd. der 22. Kavallerie⸗Brig. Am 27. Juni: Wolff, Hauptm. a. D., zuletzt im jetzigen 2. Magdeb. Inf. Regt Ne 27, und v. Wietersheim, Hauptm. a. D., zuletzt im 1. Notification respecting the manner and form in which the
renunciation by subjects and citizens of Great Britain and of
the United States respectively, of their naturalization, and the
resumption of their native allegiance, in accordance with the
Conventions of the 13th. of May 1870 and of the 23d. of Fe-
bruary 1871 concluded between Her Majesty the Queen of the
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and the Presi-
dent of the United States of America, May be Made and
declared.
Her Britannic Majesty and the President of the United
States, having concluded a Convention on the 13th. of May
1870 whereby British subjects who have become and are natu-
ralized as Ctizens of the United States are at liberty to re-
nounce their naturalization and to resume their British
nationality provided that such naturalization be publicly
declared before two years after the 12th of May 1872,
and Citizens of the United States who have become
and are naturalized as British subjects are at liberty to re-
nounce their naturalization and resume their nationality as Citi-
zens of the United States provided that such renunciation be
publicly declared within two years after the exchange of the
ratifications of the Convention, concluded a Supplementary
Convention on the 23d. of February 1871 prescribing the manner
and form in which the renunciation by the subjects of the
Contracting Parties and the resumption of their native alle-
giance may be made and publicly declared.
Copies of these two Conventions and of Her Majesty's
Order in Council declaring, as required by the 3d. Section of
the Act 33 Victoria Cap 14, that the Convention of the 13th
of May had been entered into by Her Majesty, are herewith
published for the information of all concerned, and the Under-
signed hereby calls upon all British subjects who have been
naturalized within the United States, and who may desire to
resume their allegiance as British subjects, to make the De-
claration in the form prescribed before the 12th of May 1872
in the presence of any Officer in the Diplomatic and Consular
Service of Her Majesty.
The Undersigned has further to point out that, although
the Supplemental Convention of the 23d. of February last only
requires that American Citizens who have been naturalized as
British subjects should make the Declaration of Renunciation
before a United States Court of Justice or Diplomatic or Con-
sular Officer of the United States, it will be necessary, in
order to meet the requirements of the British Act of Par-
liament, that the Declaration should also be made before one
of the British Judicial, Diplomatic, or Consular Officers
mentioned in the 3d. Section.
No fee will be levied for receiving these Declarations.
British Embassy.
Berlin, October 24th 1871.
George Petre,
H. B. M's Chargé d'affaires.
Convention between Her Majesty and the United
States of America, Supplementary to the Convention
of May 13, 1870, respecting Naturalization. — Signed
at Washington, February 23, 1871. (Ratifications
exchanged at Washington, May 4, 1871.)
Whereas by the Second Article of the Convention be-
tween Her Majesty the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great
Britain and Ireland, and the United States of America, for
regulating the citizenship of subjects and citizens of the Con-
tracting Parties who have emigrated or may emigrate from
the dominions of the one to those of the other Party, signed
at London, on the 13th of May, 1870, it was stipulated that
the manner in which the renunciation by such subjects and
citizens of their naturalization, and the resumption of their
native allegiance, may be made and publicly declared, should
be agreed upon by the Governments of the respective coun
tries; Her Majesty the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great
Britain and Ireland, and the President of the United States of
America, for the purpose of effecting such agreement, have
resolved to conclude a Supplemental Convention, and have
named as their Plenipotentiaries, that is to say: Her Majesty
the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ire-
land, Sir Edward Thornton, Knight Commander of the Most
Honourable Order of the Bath, and Her Envoy Extraordinary
and Minister Plenipotentiary to the United States of America;
and the President of the United States of America, Hamilton
Fish, Secretary of State, who have agreed as follows:
Art. I. Any person being originally a citizen of the Uni-
ted States who had, previously to May 13, 1870, been natura-
lized as a British subject, may at any time before August 10,
1872, and any British subject who, at the date first aforesaid, had
been naturalized as a citizen within the United States, may,
at any time before May 12, 1872, publicly declare his renun-

Notification respecting the manner and form in which the renunciation by subjects and citizens of Great Britain and of the United States respectively, of their naturalization, and the resumption of their native allegiance, in accordance with the Conventions of the 13th. of May 1870 and of the 23d. of Fe- bruary 1871 concluded between Her Majesty the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and the Presi- dent of the United States of America, May be Made and declared. Her Britannic Majesty and the President of the United States, having concluded a Convention on the 13th. of May 1870 whereby British subjects who have become and are natu- ralized as Ctizens of the United States are at liberty to re- nounce their naturalization and to resume their British nationality provided that such naturalization be publicly declared before two years after the 12th of May 1872, and Citizens of the United States who have become and are naturalized as British subjects are at liberty to re- nounce their naturalization and resume their nationality as Citi- zens of the United States provided that such renunciation be publicly declared within two years after the exchange of the ratifications of the Convention, concluded a Supplementary Convention on the 23d. of February 1871 prescribing the manner and form in which the renunciation by the subjects of the Contracting Parties and the resumption of their native alle- giance may be made and publicly declared. Copies of these two Conventions and of Her Majesty's Order in Council declaring, as required by the 3d. Section of the Act 33 Victoria Cap 14, that the Convention of the 13th of May had been entered into by Her Majesty, are herewith published for the information of all concerned, and the Under- signed hereby calls upon all British subjects who have been naturalized within the United States, and who may desire to resume their allegiance as British subjects, to make the De- claration in the form prescribed before the 12th of May 1872 in the presence of any Officer in the Diplomatic and Consular Service of Her Majesty. The Undersigned has further to point out that, although the Supplemental Convention of the 23d. of February last only requires that American Citizens who have been naturalized as British subjects should make the Declaration of Renunciation before a United States Court of Justice or Diplomatic or Con- sular Officer of the United States, it will be necessary, in order to meet the requirements of the British Act of Par- liament, that the Declaration should also be made before one of the British Judicial, Diplomatic, or Consular Officers mentioned in the 3d. Section. No fee will be levied for receiving these Declarations. British Embassy. Berlin, October 24th 1871. George Petre, H. B. M's Chargé d'affaires. Convention between Her Majesty and the United States of America, Supplementary to the Convention of May 13, 1870, respecting Naturalization. — Signed at Washington, February 23, 1871. (Ratifications exchanged at Washington, May 4, 1871.) Whereas by the Second Article of the Convention be- tween Her Majesty the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and the United States of America, for regulating the citizenship of subjects and citizens of the Con- tracting Parties who have emigrated or may emigrate from the dominions of the one to those of the other Party, signed at London, on the 13th of May, 1870, it was stipulated that the manner in which the renunciation by such subjects and citizens of their naturalization, and the resumption of their native allegiance, may be made and publicly declared, should be agreed upon by the Governments of the respective coun tries; Her Majesty the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and the President of the United States of America, for the purpose of effecting such agreement, have resolved to conclude a Supplemental Convention, and have named as their Plenipotentiaries, that is to say: Her Majesty the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ire- land, Sir Edward Thornton, Knight Commander of the Most Honourable Order of the Bath, and Her Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to the United States of America; and the President of the United States of America, Hamilton Fish, Secretary of State, who have agreed as follows: Art. I. Any person being originally a citizen of the Uni- ted States who had, previously to May 13, 1870, been natura- lized as a British subject, may at any time before August 10, 1872, and any British subject who, at the date first aforesaid, had been naturalized as a citizen within the United States, may, at any time before May 12, 1872, publicly declare his renun-
ciation of such naturalization by subcribing an instrument in
writing, substantially in the form hereunto appended, and de-
signated as Annex A.
Such renunciation by an original citizen of the United
States of British nationality shall, within the territories and
jurisdiction of the United States, be made in duplicate, in the
presence of any Court authorized by law for the time being
to admit aliens to naturalization, or before the Clerk or Protono-
tary of any such Court: if the declarant be beyond the territories
of the United States, it shall be made in duplicate, before any
Diplomatic or Consular officer of the United States. One of
such duplicates shall remain of record in the custody of the
Court or officer in whose presence it was made; the other
shall be, without delay, transmitted to the Department of
State.
Such renunciation, if declared by an original British sub-
ject, of his acquired nationality as a citizen of the United
States, shall, if the declarant be in the United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland, be made in duplicate, in the pre-
sence of a Justice of the Peace; if elsewhere in Her Britannic
Majesty's dominions, in triplicate, in the presence of any
Judge of civil or criminal jurisdiction, of any Justice of the
Peace, or of any other officer for the time being authorized
by law, in the place in which the declarant is, to administer
an oath for any judicial or other legal purpose: if out of Her
Majesty's dominions, in triplicate, in the presence of any offi-
cer in the Diplomatic or Consular Service of Her Majesty.
Art. II. The Contracting Parties hereby engage to com-
municate each to the other, from time to time, lists of the
persons who, within their respective dominions and territories,
or before their Diplomatic and Consular officers, have declared
their renunciation of naturalization, with the dates and places
of making such declarations, and such information as to the
abode of the declarants, and the times and places of their
naturalization, as they may have furnished.
Art. III. The present Convention shall be ratified by Her
Britannic Majesty, and by the President of the United States
by and with the advice and consent of the Senate thereof, and
the ratifications shall be exchanged at Washington as soon as
may be convenient.
In witness whereof the respective Plenipotentiaries have
signed the same, and have affixed thereto their respective
seals.
Done at Washington, the twenty-third day of February,
in the year of Our Lord one thousand eight hundred and se-
venty-one.
(L. S) Edwd. Thornton.
(L. S.) Hamilton Fish.

ciation of such naturalization by subcribing an instrument in writing, substantially in the form hereunto appended, and de- signated as Annex A. Such renunciation by an original citizen of the United States of British nationality shall, within the territories and jurisdiction of the United States, be made in duplicate, in the presence of any Court authorized by law for the time being to admit aliens to naturalization, or before the Clerk or Protono- tary of any such Court: if the declarant be beyond the territories of the United States, it shall be made in duplicate, before any Diplomatic or Consular officer of the United States. One of such duplicates shall remain of record in the custody of the Court or officer in whose presence it was made; the other shall be, without delay, transmitted to the Department of State. Such renunciation, if declared by an original British sub- ject, of his acquired nationality as a citizen of the United States, shall, if the declarant be in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, be made in duplicate, in the pre- sence of a Justice of the Peace; if elsewhere in Her Britannic Majesty's dominions, in triplicate, in the presence of any Judge of civil or criminal jurisdiction, of any Justice of the Peace, or of any other officer for the time being authorized by law, in the place in which the declarant is, to administer an oath for any judicial or other legal purpose: if out of Her Majesty's dominions, in triplicate, in the presence of any offi- cer in the Diplomatic or Consular Service of Her Majesty. Art. II. The Contracting Parties hereby engage to com- municate each to the other, from time to time, lists of the persons who, within their respective dominions and territories, or before their Diplomatic and Consular officers, have declared their renunciation of naturalization, with the dates and places of making such declarations, and such information as to the abode of the declarants, and the times and places of their naturalization, as they may have furnished. Art. III. The present Convention shall be ratified by Her Britannic Majesty, and by the President of the United States by and with the advice and consent of the Senate thereof, and the ratifications shall be exchanged at Washington as soon as may be convenient. In witness whereof the respective Plenipotentiaries have signed the same, and have affixed thereto their respective seals. Done at Washington, the twenty-third day of February, in the year of Our Lord one thousand eight hundred and se- venty-one. (L. S) Edwd. Thornton. (L. S.) Hamilton Fish.
Annex (A.).
Annex (A.).
I., A. B., of (insert abode), being originally a citizen of the
United States of America (or a British subject), and having
become naturalized within the dominions of Her Britannic
Majesty as a British subject (or as a citizen within the United
States of America), do hereby renounce my naturalization as
a British subject (or citizen of the United States); and declare
that it is my desire to resume my nationality as a citizen of
the United States (or British subject).
(Signed) A. B.
Made and subscribed before me, in
(insert country or other subdivision, and state, province,
colony, legation, or consulate), this day of
(Signed) E. F.,
Justice of the Peace (or other title).
(L. S.) Edwd. Thornton.
(L. S.) Hamilton Fish.
Convention between Her Majesty and the United States
of America relative to Naturalization. — Signed at London,
May 13, 1870. (Ratifications exchanged at London, August 10,
Her Majesty the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great
Britain and Ireland, and the President of the United States of
America, being desirous to regulate the citizenship of British
subjects who have emigrated or who may emigrate from the
British dominions to the United States of America, and of ci-
tizens of the United States of America who have emigrated
or who may emigrate from the United States of America to
the British dominions, have resolved to conclude a Convention
for that purpose, and have named as their Plenipotentiaries,
that is to say:
Her Majesty the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great
Britain and Ireland, the Right Honourable George William
Frederick, Earl of Clarendon, Baron Hyde of Hindon, a Peer
of the United Kingdom, a Member of Her Britannic Majesty's
Most Honourable Privy Council, Knight of the Most Noble
Order of the Garter, Knight Grand Cross of the Most Honou-
rable Order of the Bath, Her Britannic Majesty's Principal
Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs;
And the President of the United States of America, John
Lothrop Motley, Esquire, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister
Plenipotentiary of the United States of America to Her Bri-
tannic Majesty;
Who, after having communicated to each other their re-
spective full powers, found to be in good and due form, have
agreed upon and concluded the following Articles: —

I., A. B., of (insert abode), being originally a citizen of the United States of America (or a British subject), and having become naturalized within the dominions of Her Britannic Majesty as a British subject (or as a citizen within the United States of America), do hereby renounce my naturalization as a British subject (or citizen of the United States); and declare that it is my desire to resume my nationality as a citizen of the United States (or British subject). (Signed) A. B. Made and subscribed before me, in (insert country or other subdivision, and state, province, colony, legation, or consulate), this day of , 187. (Signed) E. F., Justice of the Peace (or other title). (L. S.) Edwd. Thornton. (L. S.) Hamilton Fish. Convention between Her Majesty and the United States of America relative to Naturalization. — Signed at London, May 13, 1870. (Ratifications exchanged at London, August 10, 1870.) Her Majesty the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and the President of the United States of America, being desirous to regulate the citizenship of British subjects who have emigrated or who may emigrate from the British dominions to the United States of America, and of ci- tizens of the United States of America who have emigrated or who may emigrate from the United States of America to the British dominions, have resolved to conclude a Convention for that purpose, and have named as their Plenipotentiaries, that is to say: Her Majesty the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, the Right Honourable George William Frederick, Earl of Clarendon, Baron Hyde of Hindon, a Peer of the United Kingdom, a Member of Her Britannic Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council, Knight of the Most Noble Order of the Garter, Knight Grand Cross of the Most Honou- rable Order of the Bath, Her Britannic Majesty's Principal Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs; And the President of the United States of America, John Lothrop Motley, Esquire, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States of America to Her Bri- tannic Majesty; Who, after having communicated to each other their re- spective full powers, found to be in good and due form, have agreed upon and concluded the following Articles: —
